Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to start my volunteer shift at the community center. It was Mia, my closest friend, texting: “Ugh, today’s been endless. Can you talk?” I could almost hear the exhaustion in her words. I knew she needed me to listen, to be there for her like I always tried to be. But just then, the volunteer coordinator gathered us, reminding everyone about the new safety steps. “No exceptions,” she said, her eyes scanning the group. I was assigned to the front desk, where I had to greet visitors and make sure every single protocol was followed. My phone wasn’t supposed to be out, and I was expected to give my full attention to the job. I stared at Mia’s message, feeling the weight of her need for support, while also hearing the coordinator’s voice in my head. My heart pounded as I wrestled with what to do—be the friend Mia needed right now, or the reliable volunteer everyone was counting on.
